title: If the Jews were so integrated in the Weimar Republic, why were there no Jewish presidents then or now? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s a fairly ridiculous question. When it is stated that Jews were well-integrated, that doesn't mean that there was not antisemitism directed at them. I mean, Irish Catholics are pretty integrated into the USA wouldn't you say? And yet JFK getting elected was a huge deal and not everyone was okay with it. Jews were integrated in that German Jews were doing their best to be “good Germans”, that doesn't mean all the Friedrichs and Helgas in the neighborhood were all welcoming and accepting. In the Weimar period, there were no Jews in a position to become either Kanzler (PM) or President but there were Jews in the Reichstag and there had been since Bismarck’s time. After WW2, few Jews remained in Germany and those that did mostly didn’t go into politics. Just over the border in Austria, however, Bruno Kreisky was the Prime Minister for a big part of the 1970s and 1980s and Kreisky was Jewish (although he did not get on well at all with the Jewish community).

The Weimar Republic had only two presidents - Ebert (1919–25) and Hindenburg (1925–34). Until 1918 Germany was a monarchy. However, there were at least two senior Jewish ministers in the Weimar period: Walther Rathenau - Wikipedia (Foreign Minister) and Hugo Preuß - Wikipedia (Interior Minister). After World War II there were very few Jews in Germany until the 1990s.
